Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War® - Soulstorm
The third and final expansion to the genre-defining and critically-acclaimed RTS, Dawn of War. In Soulstorm, two new armies are introduced – Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar - raising the total number of playable armies to nine.

Release Date: Mar 5, 2008

October 29

If You Want Blood, You've Got It!



Have you ever been playing Dawn of War II - Retribution and thought to yourself, ‘you know what this game needs more of? Blood.’? No. Neither have we but here at Relic we like to indulge in the unexpected, especially when it gives us an excuse to make the Ridiculously Bloody Blood Pack just in time for Halloween!

19 comments Read more

September 24

Relic Thanks Fans With Dawn of War Free Weekend, and Added Bonus Content



Even at more than 10 years old, the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War franchise still has a strong, passionate player base, and we at Relic would like to celebrate and show our thanks! From September 24 10AM PDT through to September 27 1PM PDT, Dawn of War I and II, plus all expansions, are free to play on Steam. As well, for new recruits, or veterans looking to complete their collection, both titles and all expansions are 75% off until September 28 at 10AM PDT. As a special thank you to all our loyal players, and as a welcome to anyone new to the franchise, we’ve also added some bonuses to DoW I and II.

• The Temple of Cyrene is a brand new, official multiplayer map we’re adding into the Dawn of War I rotation. This map will be playable in DoW the Dark Crusade and Soulstorm expansions. The Temple of Cyrene sits on the blasted landscape of a world scoured clean by the Exterminatus of the Imperial Inquisition. Homeworld of Gabriel Angelos, Cyrene is now a ghost-world of ruined cities and ashen fields. Fight for supremacy amidst the remains of Cyrene’s once-mighty temples. Claim the three critical locations at the heart of the ruins or drive into enemy bases and deliver annihilation.

• In Dawn of War II, we’re giving away four free sets of Wargear; The Vanguard, Sniper, Sternguard, and Destroyer, to equip in the main campaign that were previously only available as pre-order DLC, or as rare loot drops. Now everyone will be able to equip items like the Veteran’s Grenades, Blade of Ulyus, Armor of the Destroyer, and many more to complete your sets!

44 comments Read more

About This Game

The third and final expansion to the genre-defining and critically-acclaimed RTS, Dawn of War. In Soulstorm, two new armies are introduced – Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar - raising the total number of playable armies to nine. The revolutionary meta-game that was first introduced in Dark Crusade is further expanded to an interplanetary scale, allowing players to battle across the star system.

  • Sisters of Battle
    The Chamber Militant of the Emperor’s Holy Inquisition. Limited in numbers but incredibly powerful, the Sisters of Battle are second only to the Space Marines in terms of sheer fighting prowess. Ranging from the Sisters Repentia with their devastating ceremonial eviscerators to the awe-inspiring Penitent Engine, the Sisters of Battle are truly a force to be feared.

  • Dark Eldar
    Twisted and corrupt cousins of the Eldar, these terrifying raiders from the furthest reaches of the Webway are feared and hated by all. Their incredible speed, reliance on close quarter combat and stunning and poisoning abilities allows them to quickly strike an enemy and be gone before reinforcements can arrive.

  • Devastating air attacks
    Strategic warfare in the 41st Millennium reaches new heights as each army gains air units to rain death from the skies.

  • Brutal domination
    Wage war across the entire solar system as the metagame map introduced in Dark Crusade is expanded to an interplanetary scale. Liberate, enslave, or destroy entire worlds as you unleash your armies’ fury across the galaxy. Players must now strive to conquer an entire solar system with multiple planets and moons to be conquered. In total 34 maps are available to the player.

  • Enhanced customization
    Customize your hero’s weapons, items and abilities as he grows in power and personalize your army’s insignias, colors, banners and names. Earn and unlock achievements and medals to showcase your superiority online.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Microsoft® Windows® XP or 2000
    • Processor: 2.0 Ghz Intel Pentium 4, AMD Athlon XP or equivalent processor
    • Memory: 512 MB RAM
    • Graphics: 64 MB DirectX 9.0c compatible AGP video card with Hardware Transformation and Lighting, DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card, 16 bit
    • DirectX Version: Microsoft DirectX® 9.0c (included)
    • Hard Drive: 3.5 GB uncompressed free hard disk space
    Recommended:
    • OS: Microsoft® Windows® XP or 2000
    • Processor: 2.4 GHz Intel Pentium 4 or equivalent
    • Memory: 512 MB RAM (required for 8-player multiplayer games)
    • Graphics: nVidia GeForce 3 or equivalent with 64 MB of Video RAM
    • DirectX Version: Microsoft DirectX® 9.0c (included)
    • Hard Drive: 3.5 GB uncompressed free hard disk space
    • Sound: Sound Blaster® X-Fi™ series

How to Dawn of War - Soulstorm:
Step 1: Start a campaign as the imperium
Step 2: Do NOT fortify any strategical position for you will always be on the offensive, and this will be a waste of precious resources.
Step 3: Assault an enemy stronghold
Step 4: Mass only guardsmen (Put them in melee mode to increase their combat effectiveness by 10x!)
Step 5: Send your guardsmen at the enemy
Step 6: Victory for the Imperium!

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
20 of 20 people (100%) found this review helpful
Akfiz
67 products in account
18 reviews
Recommended
34.6 hrs on record
Posted: July 12
You already know that I'm going to recommend Soulstorm but here is what you may not know:

I) THERE'S A DEMO ON STEAM: You can always try the demo for yourself, I know I did, it should be right here on the store page

II) STANDALONE EXPANSION: You don't need the base game to enjoy the full Soulstorm experience, except for multiplayer

-x- In multiplayer, unless you have DoW:GOTY, Winter Assault & Dark Crusade you can't play with anything but Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle

-+- In every other aspect of the game you have all the races, all the possibilites, all the Soulstorm experience

CONCLUSION: You can have Soulstorm without suffering any kinds of penalities from not having the other games except the race restrictions in multiplayer. If you like this game, the other 3 aren't lesser versions of this. Each has they own campaign and their own slightly different playstyle, there are people who still play GOTY and Dark Crusade even though they have Soulstorm too, both singleplayer and multiplayer, including myself. Play the demo; if you like it -> get the game; if you want more -> pick your next game based on what you want for campaign and/or multiplayer

(examples: Infiltration doesn't work the same way in GOTY & Winter Assault as in Dark Crusade and Soulstorm, Winter Assault Imperial Guards can have as many Kasrkins and Ogryns as they like, in Dark Crusade they are limited to 1 squad, in GOTY only Chaos got Sacrificial Circle from tier 1, the lack of factions also makes a difference, etc)

III) CAMPAIGN: (This has 3 sections: STORY, CONQUEST, GAMEPLAY)

1) STORY: The story is an excuse for 9 races to fight with each other with little to no naration in it

-+- A mysterious warp storm appeared out of nowhere in the Kaurava system ruled by the Imperial Guards and Chaos start to attack them conquering one of their planets. Were Chaos brought by the warp storm ? or did they brought the warp storm themselves ?

-+- The Orks were already in the jungles on one of Kaurava system's planet and the Necrons have awakened on another planet of Kaurava system, possibly by the warp storm

-+- Eldar came to annihilate the Necron threat and so on until all other factions come on the Kaurava system with their own motivations and we have 9 factions

-x- Dark Crusade had a video for each faction's intro, Soulstorm doesn't

-x- Dark Crusade had personals dialogue between commanders for each faction attacking an enemy stronghold (main base), in Soulstorm the defending commander only has a monologue.
Dark Crusade: 6(Possible attackers)*7(strongholds)=42 possible dialogues. Soulstorm: 9 possible monologues

CONCLUSION: The story is an excuse for 9 races to fight with each other. They give you an interesting story with little to no naration in it, the only actions are your own gameplay, the 9 defending strongholds commander's monologues, the 9 faction destroyed's ending, the 42 possible aftermath of stronghold victory narations, the 9 possible endings. At that's pretty much it. The story is less narated than the Dark Crusade's one, it doesn't have constant naration like GOTY and Winter Assault's, the "naration" if we can call it that way, is pretty much what decisions you make in the conquest system, which is what stands out in the game; also used in the Dark Crusade campaign, but to a 3 to 4 times lower extent than here. The story is not the fruit of the campaign

2) CONQUEST: The soul of the campaign is a risk-like territory turn-based conquest "game" that I cannot describe in just a few words so I'm just going to call it conquest

-+- Basically it's an interplanetary war where you decide what to attack when to attack in a graphical interface, the gameplay outside the gameplay, only when you start a battle for a territory you go in the actual gameplay with troops and stuff

-+- The gameplay isn't just plan gameplay, a lot of the gameplay is affected by the decisions you make in conqest (example: you can have a honor guard, troops more powerful than average that are already deployed in the field when you start the battle for a territory, you can buy troops & buildings reinforcements for a territory and have them already on the field/built when you are being attacked; you can unlock wargear that increases your commander's or army's various stats during the gameplay)

-+- Each faction has a personal bonus (forward base, speed, deep strike, etc) and there are a few territories that giving you bonuses. The others give you new possible buyings for the honor guard

-+- If you destroy a faction you get their personal bonus for yourself (but not all their territories too)

-+- You still got wargear, you still got honor guards, you still got regional bonuses (even more now)

-+- You get to kill Dark Eldars with Orks (or poiny ears tall men something as they call them)

-+- The computer isn't cheating, he just gets more skilled as you increase the campaign difficulty

-x- Unlike Dark Crusade, you can't build massive defence on territories you control. All you can build is basic units and structures, but it kinda doesn't make sense since nothing basically stops you from building defences on your territories. Except that would make the game unbalanced, if this was also true for your enemies you have a very hard time attacking them, it's one thing to start with a disadvantage, and another to start with a complete disadvantage. I guess they could have made it into a full-scale war game instead, but if this didn't happened, it's better for balance not to do this. I personally have abused this in Dark Crusade, can't do the same in Soulstorm.
(In Dark Crusade, you don't really have the option to upgrade everything on defending territories, but when you attack and conquer a territory your buildings would "save" for when you are attacked)

-x- Commander Boreale of the Space Marines

-x- People who prefer linear campaigns instead are going to be dissapointed. (Including myself, but this kind of campaign was a huge succes, lots of people liked it more than the older generic one, so I've got to be objective on this one: the campaign conquest system is good, very good. I don't hate this campaign mode, I actually like it, but I just liked the linear ones more)

3) GAMEPLAY: Basically: the same as the other DoW1 games, actually: it has some new units/ improvements/ differences

-+- Squad based system

-+- The most active multiplayer in the Dawn of War 1 series. Everytime I check there are about 90 players in the lobby an 10 servers
(Out of wich 6-9 will have password but this is probably because if you create a game you won't have a hard/long time finding players to play with)

-+- There is no gamespy anymore
(You don't have to register in 7.000 locations to play online anymore, just start the game on steam, click online, and voila)

-+- In campaign mode, you get a few extra stuff depending on what you do in the conquest, the enemy does too

-+- You have many skirmish maps, about 100

-?- Sisters of Battle got "Faith" and Dark Eldar got their soul harvesting. Orks are no longer the only unit with a unique resource
(Some may like it, some may not, I think it's ok)

-?- Air units have been added
(Some claimed that air units don't fit with the gameplay. You have only 1 air vehicle per race and they're not tanks, but you should use them for tactical purposes, I feel that this kinda does fit with the gameplay but I'm no pro to make a statement, anyway for a regular gamer is a nice add-on, adds variety of tactics)

-x- 9 races with only 8 maximum slots ? no each race FFA possible :(

!?! Some people complained that the Eldar are too overpowered in multiplayer. However, I haven't personally seen some eldar flood online. I have no ideea whether this is true or false
In Dark Crusade some said the necrons are OP

IV) OTHERS: Paint your army the way you like it

9.50/10 - the overwhelmingly positive reviews are well diserved
